title: My Weird Winter Obsession: That Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so. I was sitting there, my hands were like sandpaper. It’s that time of year, you know? The air gets all mean and dry and everything just itches. My knuckles looked like a cracked desert. I was scrolling, probably looking at memes, and this ad pops up for a tallow balm. Bourbon vanilla scent. And I just stared at it. Beef fat. For your face. I think I actually said “what” out loud to my empty living room. The neighbor’s dog barked back. It was a whole thing.

But my hands. They were so bad. I’d tried that fancy stuff in the blue bottle, the one that costs like thirty bucks and smells like a hospital. Nothing. Zip. So I was desperate. And maybe a little curious. Like, how weird could it be? Putting beef tallow on your skin. It sounds like something your great-grandmother might have done before they invented, I don’t know, everything. But the shop had good reviews. Pictures of happy-looking jars. I was drinking a beer, it was a Tuesday night, and I just clicked it. The Whipped Tallow Balm. Bourbon Vanilla. From some small shop on Etsy. I figured if it was gross, I’d just hide it in the back of a drawer and never speak of it again.

It showed up a week later. I was half-expecting it to come in a greasy paper bag.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

The jar was actually nice. Simple. I unscrewed the lid and just. Sniffed it. I had to. And it didn’t smell like beef. Or fat. It smelled like… vanilla. But not like cake. More like the vanilla bean paste I splurged on once for cookies. Warm. Kind of cozy? I poked it with a finger. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter but… fluffier. Whipped, I guess. That’s what it says. Whipped beef tallow balm. I scooped a tiny bit and rubbed it between my fingers. It melted. Like, instantly. Into nothing. No grease. Just… gone. My skin just drank it. And it was soft. Actually soft. For the first time in months.

I sat there for a minute just looking at my hands. This is so dumb, I thought. But it worked. Better than anything else. So I got brave. I put a little on my cheek. Where it gets all tight and angry in the winter. Same thing. Melted. Absorbed. My face didn’t feel like it was wearing a mask. It just felt… normal. Hydrated. Not shiny. Just my skin, but happier. I was baffled. And weirdly excited. I texted my friend: “you will not believe what I just put on my face.” She texted back a bunch of question marks.

But here’s the thing I looked up after, because I had to know *why* this beef tallow skincare thing wasn’t a complete disaster.

## Why Beef Tallow for Skin Actually Makes Sense

It sounds insane. I get it. I was right there with you. Beef fat? On my face? But then I fell down a rabbit hole one night instead of sleeping. And it turns out it’s not that crazy. Tallow, especially from grass-fed cows, is weirdly similar to the oils our own skin makes. That sebum stuff. So your skin kinda recognizes it. It’s like giving your skin something it already knows how to use, instead of some lab-made chemical soup it has to figure out. This stuff just gets absorbed. Deep. It doesn’t just sit on top like a slick. It goes in and does the job.

I read that this particular balm is made in France from grass-fed suet, whipped up into this light texture. It mimics human sebum. That’s the sciencey bit, I guess. All I know is my skin stopped feeling like it was at war with the atmosphere. My chapped lips? Gone in two days. The rough patches on my elbows I’ve had since forever? Smooth. I don’t know how else to say it. It just… works. It’s good for dry skin. Really good. My hands don’t crack and bleed when I make a fist anymore. That’s the real test.

It’s the opposite of what you’d expect. You think: grease, clogged pores, smell like a kitchen. But it’s none of that. It’s just a balm that fixes the problem. I keep it on my nightstand now. Next to my water glass and a pile of old receipts.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been like, a month maybe? I’m bad with time. But I’m on my second jar. I ordered another one before I even ran out because I got paranoid. That’s how much I like it. The bourbon vanilla scent is just… it’s not perfume-y. It’s not strong. It’s just this warm, comforting smell when you open the jar. It doesn’t linger on your skin, which I like. It’s just a nice little moment when you’re putting it on. Cozy. Like a blanket for your face.

My winter routine is stupid simple now. Wash face. Pat dry. Little bit of the tallow balm. Done. I don’t need three different serums and a cream that costs a car payment. I just need this one weird jar from that Etsy shop. I told my mom about it. She was horrified at first. Then I gave her my almost-empty first jar to try on her gardening hands. She texted me a week later asking for the link. That’s the real endorsement, right?

The weirdness factor totally wears off. Now it’s just my balm. The one that works. When people ask “is tallow good for skin?” I just show them my hands. Or my face, which hasn’t had a single flaky patch all season. That’s the answer. It’s a yes. A big, surprising, buttery-soft yes.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, honestly. It sounds wild but it makes sense once you get past the idea. It’s really similar to the oils our skin already produces, so it absorbs well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. My face has never been happier in the winter.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me, and I can get clogged pores pretty easy. It absorbs so fast it doesn’t just sit there. It’s not like slathering on Vaseline. It’s more like giving your skin a drink it actually wants.

**What does the bourbon vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s like a warm, cozy vanilla. Not sugary sweet. More like the good vanilla extract you cook with, but softer. It’s really comforting and the smell doesn’t stick around, it’s just nice when you apply it.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult with the cold, and you’re tired of stuff that doesn’t work… might be worth a shot. It’s just one of those things you have to try to get it. I’m just glad I got past my own weirdness about it. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
